reference.title: Backing up and restoring applications
reference.shortdesc: Having accurate and tested backups can mitigate problems caused by software or hardware issues. can back up and restore the entire and application installation.

refbody.section:
You can back up configuration information and data from an application and then later restore that instance. Back up on a regular schedule to provide a historical archive. Back up as needed when you perform less-frequent tasks such as moving data from one instance to another or duplicating an instance for testing or failover purposes.
Before undertaking any of the following actions, ensure that you have a recent backup that successfully restores:
Upgrading - Perform a daily backup and take a VM snapshot.
Testing - Weekly, perform restore testing and confirm that data is recent.
Using a temporary VM or DR site.
When a full backup is not necessary, such as when you need a checkpoint prior to installing software, you can perform a snapshot of the system. If you need to revert back to a snapshot, use the rollback feature. Before rolling back, you must stop services that are used in the particular snapshot image. For more information, see .
About backups
Perform regular backups of the production environment and potentially the system of record from the initial deployment. Back up to nonactive resource targets such as separate DR systems, or a DEV, STAGING, or QA environment. Store backups on a machine other than the master. Copy or migrate backups to an off-system location for safekeeping and to help regulate storage space usage on the master.
The backup process saves the state of all services and data to a .tgz file that you can restore on that cluster or duplicate on a similar cluster. The state of the system at the time of the backup is stored; however, specific snapshots are not backed up. When a backup is running, you can start and restart services.
You can use either the browser interface or the command line interface to back up and restore applications. However, backups that you took using 1.0.x cannot be restored in 1.1.x or later versions.
About restores
You can restore a backup to the system on which it was taken or to an alternate system. Restoring to the same system reverts the resource host, its service configuration, and the application state to the point in time when the backup was taken. The system on which you restore any backup should mirror at least one device from the production system.
Frequently test restoring from a backup to ensure that the backup restores successfully, and that the restored system is an accurate representation of the state of the deployment when the backup was performed. Because snapshots are loaded to disk, during a restore you are not required to stop services while the file is loaded. Though the restore will not complete successfully, the snapshot and images are available for you to manually rollback each application.
If an outage occurs during a restore from a backup, you can resume the restore. preserves complete data on your system. For example, you ran a restore and two of the six backed up snapshots were restored before an outage. Those two snapshots are saved on the system, and are not downloaded again from the backup file when you resume the restore.
If you manually deleted the default pool, you cannot restore from a backup. The default pool is created on startup and is required.
